instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: Water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> along with all resistors and caps in that area and a few jumper wires. Suck at 5v at 0amp on all usb c ports. I do have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: Possible broken trace, lost connection with <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: Thats not what i was hoping to hear. Sounds like even more of a nightmare then its already been.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> connects to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with some traces inside PCB.
I trashed one board for this issue some time ago...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: So i actually got it to boot. After testing and comparing diode readings to another board it looks like <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> wasn't getting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> but the rest of the board was so after one more jumper wire we have 20v and it boots!!!!!. But its a 2016 so its got flexgate.... time to call the customer and tell them something I'm sure they already know but failed to mention....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: Oh and Critical update failed. Even better

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: You are lucky getting experience at least; in case the client retires it without finishing the repair.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message: Alright so digging into the critical update issue. Ran diode mode on both touch bar connectors and compared to a know good board. found a I had a broken line to pin 20 and 21 on J4402 for the touch bar ran yet another jumper but still getting error. Testing with a known good display and top case and USB OS. SSD can be accessed with lifeboat in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v 0amp
threads.message:
Few posts on the forum refer to this issue.
We didn't get feedback if any works; just try...
